trans-unit.source: Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add a page or application to your instance of Azure App Service Web Apps that is already configured to use Java.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add a page or application to your instance of Azure App Service Web Apps that is already configured to use Java.

trans-unit.source: Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: Once you have initialized your Java web app in [Azure App Service][] as documented at [Create a Java web app in Azure App Service](web-sites-java-get-started.md), you can upload your application by placing your WAR in the **webapps** folder.
trans-unit.target: Once you have initialized your Java web app in [Azure App Service][] as documented at [Create a Java web app in Azure App Service](web-sites-java-get-started.md), you can upload your application by placing your WAR in the **webapps** folder.

trans-unit.source: The navigation path to the **webapps** folder differs based on how you set up your Web Apps instance.
trans-unit.target: The navigation path to the **webapps** folder differs based on how you set up your Web Apps instance.

trans-unit.source: If you set up your web app by using the Azure Marketplace, the path to the **webapps** folder is in the form **d:\home\site\wwwroot\bin\application\_server\webapps**, where **application\_server** is the name of the application server in effect for your Web Apps instance.
trans-unit.target: If you set up your web app by using the Azure Marketplace, the path to the **webapps** folder is in the form **d:\home\site\wwwroot\bin\application\_server\webapps**, where **application\_server** is the name of the application server in effect for your Web Apps instance.

trans-unit.source: If you set up your web app by using the Azure configuration UI, the path to the **webapps** folder is in the form **d:\home\site\wwwroot\webapps**.
trans-unit.target: If you set up your web app by using the Azure configuration UI, the path to the **webapps** folder is in the form **d:\home\site\wwwroot\webapps**.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can use source control to upload your application or web pages, including continuous integration scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can use source control to upload your application or web pages, including continuous integration scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Instructions for using source control with your web app are available at [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: Instructions for using source control with your web app are available at [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.source: FTP is also an option for uploading your application or web pages.
trans-unit.target: FTP is also an option for uploading your application or web pages.

trans-unit.source: Note for Tomcat web apps: Once you've uploaded your WAR file to the **webapps** folder, the Tomcat application server will detect that you've added it and will automatically load it.
trans-unit.target: Note for Tomcat web apps: Once you've uploaded your WAR file to the **webapps** folder, the Tomcat application server will detect that you've added it and will automatically load it.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you copy files (other than WAR files) to the ROOT directory, the application server will need to be restarted before those files are used.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you copy files (other than WAR files) to the ROOT directory, the application server will need to be restarted before those files are used.

trans-unit.source: The autoload functionality for the Tomcat Java web apps running on Azure is based on a new WAR file being added, or new files or directories added to the **webapps** folder.
trans-unit.target: The autoload functionality for the Tomcat Java web apps running on Azure is based on a new WAR file being added, or new files or directories added to the **webapps** folder.
